title: UAE lobbied Netanyahu to accept Trump Gaza plan: Report
summary:
UAE lobbied Netanyahu to accept Trump Gaza plan: Report

The UAE lobbied Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to accept President Donald Trumpâ€™s Gaza peace proposal and to abandon plans to annex the occupied West Bank, Reuters reported on Monday. 

The UAE position on Trump's Gaza peace plan was delivered to Netanyahu by its Foreign Minister,  Abdullah bin Zayed, on the sidelines of the UN General Assembly in New York on Friday, Reuters said. 

The UAE told Netanyahu that annexation would prevent the expansion of the Abraham Accords to countries like Indonesia and Saudi Arabia.

title: Israel detains dozens of Palestinians in occupied West Bank
summary:
Israel detains dozens of Palestinians in occupied West Bank

Israel arbitrarily detained dozens of Palestinians at checkpoints in the occupied West Bank on Monday, according to Palestinian news agency Wafa. 

Around 20 young Palestinian men were detained at the Atara military checkpoint, located to the north of Ramallah city.

According to Wafa, Israel has ramped up arbitrary restrictions and detentions in the area.

title: White House says both sides need to make concessions in Gaza for a ceasefire
summary:
White House says both sides need to make concessions in Gaza for a ceasefire

The White House said both Hamas and Israel need to make concessions in order for a ceasefire in Gaza. 

The comments from Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt come as US President Donald Trump is set to meet Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu at the White House.

title: Ousted head of Algerian intelligence 'flees country aboard speedboat'
summary:
Ousted head of Algerian intelligence 'flees country aboard speedboat'

Submitted by MEE staff on Mon, 09/29/2025 - 14:49
Major General Abdelkader Haddad, under house arrest in Algiers since his dismissal in May, feared for his life and reached Spain by sea, reports Spanish newspaper El Confidencial
Algerian soldiers parade down a street in the capital Algiers on 5 July 2022, as the country celebrates the 60th anniversary of its independence (Ryad Kramdi/AFP)
Off

One of Algeria's most powerful military figures who recently fell from grace, Major General Abdelkader Haddad, fled the country aboard a speedboat for Spain fearing for his life, according to Spanish newspaper El Confidencial.

Haddad, better known by his nickname Nasser El Djinn (â€œthe Devilâ€), headed the General Directorate of Internal Security (DGSI), Algeria's most influential intelligence service, for nearly a year.

He was dismissed in May for unspecified reasons, after which he was incarcerated in military prisons and then placed under house arrest in an upscale Algiers neighbourhood. He was due to be tried soon.

The charges against the former close associate of President Abdelmadjid Tebboune, whose re-election Haddad supported in September 2024, remain unknown.

Observers presume his fall from grace is due to investigations he launched into suspected corruption and profiteering involving high-ranking families with ties to the ruling class.

According to El Confidencial journalist Ignacio Cembrero, Haddad managed to elude the Algerian military police and escape in the early hours of 19 September.

Sources in the Algerian diaspora and Spanish police told Cembrero that Haddad crossed the Mediterranean by boat and reached Alicante.

Upon arriving in the city in southern Spain, where he owns property, Haddad told sources he fled because he knew he would be killed before appearing before a judge and his death would be presented as a suicide.

Shortly before El Confidencial's revelations, Le Monde reported that Haddad's disappearance had led to a massive security deployment in Algiers and its outskirts on 18 and 19 September, with police and military roadblocks, vehicle searches causing massive traffic jams, and helicopters flying over the area.

While Algerian authorities and media kept quiet about Haddadâ€™s escape, rumours began to circulate about his whereabouts, with some Algerian influencers living abroad relaying reports that he had surrendered to the authorities.

Clan struggles

According to Le Monde, Haddadâ€™s escape sent shockwaves through the top brass, as it could only have happened owing to complicity within the security apparatus.

The incident, according to the French newspaper, reveals the divisions and recurring instability within the Algerian political and security system, and is said to have fuelled tensions between the president and the army chief of staff, Said Chengriha, amid suspicions of a coup d'etat being plotted.

Algeria has had five heads of the DGSI and seven heads of the foreign intelligence service since Tebboune came to power in 2019.

Algeria bans Gaza march amid fears of political unrest
Read More Â»

Since the Hirak, the mass protest movement that led to the ousting of longtime ruler Abdelaziz Bouteflika in 2019, purges have become cyclical in the country. Le Monde counts around 200 senior officers, including 30 generals, behind bars.

According to analysts, the mechanisms within the Algerian security system that previously served to conceal internal tensions started to break down in 2015 when Bouteflika and his army chief Ahmed Gaid Salah decided to disband the Intelligence and Security Department (DRS), which coordinated domestic, foreign and military intelligence services, under the leadership of Mohamed â€œToufikâ€ Mediene.

This shook the system formed around the three main actors of Algerian power - the army, the presidency and the DRS - at a time when Bouteflika was encouraging the rise of oligarchs, thereby introducing a fourth pole of influence where profiteering practices were rife.

For Cembrero, who points out that Haddad himself has been accused of committing atrocities during the civil war in the 1990s, the escape highlights "the clan struggles" that have persisted within the Algerian army for nearly a decade.

"The seemingly most powerful generals can find themselves behind bars overnight," he wrote.

Inside Algeria
News

0

Mon, 05/04/2020 - 21:19
Update Date Override

title: A breakdown of Tony Blairâ€™s bizarre proposal to run Gaza
summary:
A breakdown of Tony Blairâ€™s bizarre proposal to run Gaza

Submitted by Rayhan Uddin on Mon, 09/29/2025 - 14:36
Proposed transitional authority will have global billionaires and businesspeople at top and Palestinians at bottom, according to leaked draft
Former British prime minister Tony Blair speaks at a session during the World Economic Forum (WEF) annual meeting in Davos on 22 January 2025 (AFP/Fabrice Coffrini)
Off

An unlikely answer has been found for who should lead the process of running Gaza after Israelâ€™s genocidal war: Tony Blair. 

It was revealed last week that the former British prime minister - a controversial figure in the Middle East, to say the least - was being considered to lead a transitional authority in the enclave. 

Haaretz has now published a leaked draft plan of what Gaza would look like under Blairâ€™s initiative. 

The plan reveals a hierarchy in which an international board of billionaires and businesspeople sit at the top, while highly vetted "neutral" Palestinian administrators are at the bottom. 

It sets out a three-year plan, budgeted at $90m in the first year, $134m in the second and $164m in the third (these are solely management expenses, and donâ€™t include reconstruction or aid). 

The administration would work closely with Israel, Egypt and the US, and, according to Israeli sources cited by Haartez, has the backing of the White House. 

Middle East Eye breaks down key highlights from the 21-page leaked document. 

Board of billionaires

Gaza International Transitional Authority, or Gita, is the name given to the new institution which will administer the Palestinian enclave. 

According to the draft, Gita will be run by an international board which has â€œsupreme political and legal authority for Gaza during the transitional periodâ€.

The board will be in charge of all appointments, and supervise every component of the authority. 

It will be made up of between seven and 10 members, including a chair. 

The board will include a senior UN official, with Sigrid Kaag, the UNâ€™s special coordinator for the Middle East peace process, cited as an example. 

It would also include â€œleading international figures with executive and financial expertiseâ€. 

Three names are cited as potential candidates: Marc Rowan, a billionaire who owns one of Americaâ€™s largest private equity firms, Naguib Sawiris, an Egyptian billionaire in the telecommunications and technology sector, and Aryeh Lightstone, chief executive of the Abraham Accords Peace Institute.

Lightstone was a senior adviser to David Friedman, a staunch defender of Israelâ€™s illegal settlement movement, when he was US ambassador to Israel between 2017 and 2021 under Donald Trumpâ€™s first administration.

Tony Blair's controversial relationship with the Middle East since leaving office
Read More Â»

According to Haaretz, he was also deeply involved in the creation of the highly controversial Gaza Humanitarian Foundation. 

Not every single board member will be a billionaire or have links to Israel or America. 

There will be â€œat least one qualified Palestinian representativeâ€, potentially coming from the â€œbusiness or security sectorâ€. It wasnâ€™t made clear what â€œqualifiedâ€ means.

And finally, the document said that the board would have â€œa strong representation of Muslim members to ensure regional legitimacy and cultural credibilityâ€.

These Muslim figures would ideally have the political support of their countries, but also â€œlong standing business credibilityâ€. 

Members of the board would be â€œnominated by contributing states and confirmed through a process coordinated by the UNâ€. 

The board would report to the UN Security Council, which would ultimately grant it authority to carry out its functions. 

The Security Council currently includes non-permanent members that have been highly critical of Israelâ€™s genocide in Gaza, such as Algeria, Pakistan and Slovenia, in addition to permanent members Russia and China.

It would be interesting to see if these countries would approve a transitional government in Gaza run mostly by non-Palestinian billionaires and business figures. 

The chairman (probably Blair)

Various media outlets have reported that Blair is being touted to be the chair of the transitional authority, though his name is not mentioned in the draft. 

Public-private partnerships to run government projects, one of Blairâ€™s hallmark policies as prime minister of the UK, is mentioned in the document. 

According to the draft plan, the chairman will serve as the â€œsenior political executive, principal spokesperson, and strategic coordinator for the entire transitional authorityâ€. 

Trump Gaza plan: Blair joins the vultures feeding on a Palestinian Holocaust
Read More Â»

They would be appointed through â€œinternational consensusâ€ and endorsement by the UN Security Council. There is no mention of Palestinian consensus in choosing them. 

If Blair is indeed the proposed chairman, he may have his work cut out gaining â€œinternational consensusâ€ for his appointment. 

His handling of the Iraq war as premier of the UK, as well as his dealings with a string of autocrats, has left him deeply unpopular across the globe. 

The chair will represent Gita â€œin all diplomatic, donor and intergovernmental forumsâ€. They will also lead â€œstrategic security diplomacyâ€ with other actors, â€œincluding Israel, Egypt and the United Statesâ€. 

The document notes that initially, Gitaâ€™s senior officials wonâ€™t be in Gaza. 

In the first year, theyâ€™ll be based in â€œcoordination cellsâ€ such as El-Arish in Egyptâ€™s Sinai and â€œremote policy hubsâ€ such as Cairo and Amman. 

There would be partial deployment into Gaza by the second year, before â€œfull operatationalisationâ€ into the enclave in the third year. 

Hierarchical structure

An organisational chart at the end of the document lays out the hierarchical structure of Gita, with the board and chairman at the top. 

A security body, the â€œInternational Security Forceâ€, is on the same row as the board and chairman and appears to be outside of the hierarchy. 

This body will man crossings into Gaza, naval approaches and â€œperimeter zonesâ€ in coordination with Israel and Egypt. 

It will also run â€œtargeted operations to prevent the resurgence of armed groupsâ€.

There is no mention of Hamas in the entire document.

Directly underneath the board and the chairman will be a number of bodies and structures - none of which appear to be directly Palestinian-run - including an investment and economic development authority and an â€œexecutive secretariatâ€.

The latter will coordinate daily operations, including digital creating systems to identify Palestinians in Gaza and â€œdigital platforms for licensing and permitsâ€.

Below that layer are several officials overseeing humanitarian work, reconstruction, legislative and legal issues, and security, as well as a coordinator with the Palestinian Authority (PA).

It is below this, at the very bottom of the chart, where we see named Palestinian involvement: the â€œPalestinian Executive Authorityâ€.

Palestinian Executive Authority, with little authority

Despite the name, the Palestinian Executive Authority, at the bottom of the hierarchy, has little to no independent authority. 

It is separate from the PA, which administers parts of the occupied West Bank.

It would be made up of technocratic ministries that administer health, education, water supply and energy, labour market policies, housing, local criminal justice and welfare, among a few other policy areas. 

It would be headed up by a â€œPalestinian Chief Executive Officerâ€, appointed by the international board. 

Recognition of Palestine is a repeat of the Westâ€™s Oslo 'peace' fraud
Read More Â»

Itâ€™s notable that the language used for all roles throughout the document, like board, chairman and CEO, reflects a business structure rather than a country or territory. 

The Palestinian CEO will lead the process of identifying â€œdirectorsâ€ (not ministers) to head up the various departments like health, education, infrastructure and planning. 

The directors will need to â€œmeet standards of technical competence, integrity, and neutralityâ€. 

The international board of billionaires and businesspeople will have the final say on appointments â€œto safeguard institutional legitimacy and independenceâ€. 

â€œAll department heads are subject to performance review and can be dismissed or replaced in accordance with transitional governance procedures,â€ the document notes. 

An Israeli source told Haaretz that the Palestinian Executive Authority would be completely subordinate to the board and have no independent authority. 

As such, it would be far weaker than the technocratic administration set out in a joint Arab plan led by Egypt earlier this year. 

Below the Palestinian Executive Authority are a number of municipal roles related to the running of local public services and utilities. 

â€œAll mayors and senior municipal administrators are nominated by the Palestinian Executive Authority and formally appointed by the GITA International Board,â€ the plan states. 

Once again, it is also spelled out that any Palestinian appointees to such roles â€œmust meet strict standards of political neutralityâ€. 

It is not spelled out whether the likes of Aryeh Lightstone, the pro-Israel former adviser named in the document as a potential board member, is considered â€œpolitically neutralâ€.

International law

There are various judicial and legal arms to the authority, too. 

That includes a legislative and legal supervisor who, among other things, would ensure that the transitional authority was operating in a manner â€œconsistent with international lawâ€. 

Given how closely this authority states that it will work with Israel, which has been breaching international law in the West Bank and Gaza for over seven decades, it will have its work cut out. 

There will also be a â€œjudicial boardâ€ to oversee due process, legal compliance and justice sector reforms. 

The board will be â€œchaired by a reputable Arab jurist, preferably Palestinianâ€. 

Interestingly, one of its roles will include legally protecting the â€œright to returnâ€ for any Palestinian in Gaza who decides to voluntarily leave their home. 

â€œGITA does not facilitate or endorse population relocation but ensures that all voluntary movement is conducted in accordance with international law and rights protections,â€ the plan states. 

Palestinians will likely be sceptical of any such promises, particularly from an authority that will have Israeli backing. 

During the Nakba in 1948, when 750,000 Palestinians were forced from their homes in what is now Israel, many thought they would be gone for just days. Over 77 years later, they still have not been allowed to return. 

The draft plan mentions that Gita will work â€œin close consultationâ€ with the PA, with a view to eventually handing management over to it. 

It doesnâ€™t set out a timetable for when this will happen. 

Israel's genocide in Gaza

title: Netanyahu arrives in Washington for meeting with Trump
summary:
Netanyahu arrives in Washington for meeting with Trump

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has arrived in Washington for a meeting with US President Donald Trump.

The pair are set to discuss Trump's 21-point Gaza peace plan. White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt told Fox news earlier that Israel and Hamas are "very close" to securing a deal.

title: Labour Party conference: Will Palestinians get a mention in Starmerâ€™s speech?
summary:
Labour Party conference: Will Palestinians get a mention in Starmerâ€™s speech?

Submitted by Jeremy Corbyn on Mon, 09/29/2025 - 10:15
The legacy of Keir Starmer's government will be its complicity in one of the greatest crimes against humanity of our times
An image of Britain's Prime Minister Keir Starmer is pictured on promotional material on the first day of the annual Labour Party conference in Liverpool, north-west England, on 28 September 2025 (AFP)
On

This week is the Labour Party conference. I have sent my apologies. Iâ€™ll be in South Africa for a Palestine Solidarity Tour, alongside Mustafa Barghouti, the leader and founder of the Palestinian National Initiative.

It was South Africa that launched a case against Israel at the International Court of Justrice (ICJ), accusing Israel of genocide. 

I had the honour of attending that case. It was a momentous display of international solidarity from a people who know what itâ€™s like to endure - and dismantle - apartheid.

At the time of the speech of Keir Starmer, the British prime minister, I will be at the Nelson Mandela Foundation in Johannesburg.

Following the news of a ceasefire deal in Gaza last January, the foundation posted on its website that: "There must be an acknowledgement of â€“ and accountability for â€“ what Palestinians have endured since late 2023."

The Gaza Tribunal 

During my transit to South Africa, I continued work on our report, following the Gaza Tribunal we hosted earlier this month.

Our tribunal was a two-day inquiry into Britainâ€™s role in Israeli war crimes in Gaza.

How UK bureaucracy enables Israel's genocide
Katie Fallon
Read More Â»

We heard from a range of survivors, witnesses, as well as a range of international law experts, lawyers and whistleblowers.

That included Dr Nick Maynard and Dr Victoria Rose, who gave harrowing testimonies of their experiences working in hospitals in Gaza.

They recalled the haunting screams of children, whose limbs were amputated without anaesthetic. 

Perhaps the most damning indictment of British complicity was from Mark Smith, a British Foreign Office official who resigned in protest over continued arms sales to Israel. 

He described how he was routinely asked to amend his reports on the legality of arms exports so they "sounded less bad".

Inquiry - take two

Earlier this year I tried to present a Bill to Parliament for an independent, Chilcot-style public inquiry into Britainâ€™s support for Israeli military operations in Gaza, but it was blocked by the government.

Just like Iraq, the UK government is doing everything it can to protect itself from scrutiny. Just like Iraq, it will not succeed

The governmentâ€™s official response states that "there is no need for an inquiry" and "such an inquiry would be unnecessary as there is no confusion about UK military operations in Gaza".

Once we have finalised our Tribunal Report, we will be presenting it to the government. We will, once again, be demanding an official, public inquiry into British complicity.

It is worth noting that we held the Tribunal at Church House. It was here that I made an apology on behalf of the Labour Party for its disastrous decision to invade Iraq.

Unfortunately, this was not the last time a Labour prime minister has appointed himself the messiah of the free world.

Today, history is repeating itself. Just like Iraq, the government is doing everything it can to protect itself from scrutiny. Just like Iraq, it will not succeed in its attempts to hide the truth. 

A reckoning is coming

Earlier this month, the UN Independent International Commission of Inquiry confirmed that Israel has committed genocide in Gaza. The UN report has significant implications for British ministers and officials.

Those who still deny the Gaza genocide are complicit in Israel's atrocities 
Read More Â»

Time and time again, we have reminded the government of its legal and moral obligations to prevent genocide. Time and time again, our calls have been met with evasion, obfuscation and denial.

To this day, we still do not know what legal advice the government has received on an assessment of genocide, or whether that advice will be made public.

No one can pretend they did not know what was happening. Today, some politicians have finally started to backtrack.

We have noticed their change in rhetoric, but we will never forget their moral cowardice when it mattered the most.

Today, schoolchildren are taught about historyâ€™s worst crimes against humanity. In the future, our history books will shame those who enabled one of the greatest crimes of our time.

This governmentâ€™s legacy will be its complicity in one of the greatest crimes against humanity of the century. 

A real political choice

I need not watch the prime ministerâ€™s speech to know what he will say: defence, defence, defence.

The government has not been generous to children in poverty or the disabled. But there is one area where the government has been very generous indeed. That area is arms spending: new nuclear weapons, more nuclear-powered submarines, and more F35 planes from the USA.

Recognition of Palestine is a repeat of the Westâ€™s Oslo 'peace' fraud
Jonathan Cook
Read More Â»

The government could have pursued a foreign policy that defends human rights and brings about peace.

Instead, as images of starving children circulate around the world, our government has ensured it will be remembered for the human suffering it has refused to alleviate. 

It is abundantly clear that people are yearning for something different; for a world that cares for each other and cares for all.

That is why we have launched a new kind of political party. One that harnesses the collective call for peace. One that believes in the equal value of all human life. One that will always stand with the people of Palestine. 

Our founding conference will be very different from Labour's. It will vow to stop, rather than deny, the genocide in Gaza. It will empower members to shape the future of our party and our country. And it will kickstart a mass, democratic movement that will finally offer people hope in a more equal, sustainable and peaceful world. 

If you want to be part of this, you just need to become a member of yourparty.uk. This is how you can take Your Party into your hands. This is how you can help build a real alternative. This is how you can bring something rare back into politics: hope. 

For too long, people have been denied a real political choice. Not anymore. 

The views expressed in this article belong to the author and do not necessarily reflect the editorial policy of Middle East Eye. 

Gaza extermination
Starmerâ€™s Labour has enabled genocide. Now a new party of peace will fight injustice

title: Israeli attack on Gaza City kills two
summary:
Israeli attack on Gaza City kills two

An Israeli attack on Gaza City has killed at least two people, Al Jazeera is reporting, citing medical sources.

According to sources at al-Shifa Hospital, the attack struck al-Thalathini Street in central Gaza.

The Palestinian health ministry in Gaza reported earlier on Monday that at least 50 Palestinians, including five aid seekers, were killed in Israeli attacks across the enclave in the last 24 hours.

Most of the victims were killed in attacks on Gaza City, where Israel is escalating its military assault.

title: White House says 'very close' to Gaza peace deal ahead of Netanyahu meeting with Trump
summary:
White House says 'very close' to Gaza peace deal ahead of Netanyahu meeting with Trump

Israel and Hamas are "very close" to reaching a Gaza peace deal, White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt told Fox News.

Leavitt said President Donald Trump would outline a 21-point peace plan with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu at the White House on Monday.

Also on Monday, Trump is set to speak to leaders in Qatar, who have served as intermediaries with Hamas, she added.

"To reach a reasonable deal for both sides, both sides have to give up a little bit and might leave the table a little bit unhappy, but that is ultimately how we are going to end this conflict," she said.

The meeting is set to take place at 11am local time (3pm GMT).

Reporting by Reuters

title: UAE urges Netanyahu to accept Trump Gaza plan
summary:
UAE urges Netanyahu to accept Trump Gaza plan

The UAE has urged Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to accept US President Donald Trump's Gaza peace proposal ahead of a meeting between the two on Monday, a delegate told Reuters.

According to the delegate, UAE Foreign Minister Sheikh Abdullah bin Zayed also warned Netanyahu in a meeting at the UN General Assembly in New York on Friday to abandon plans to annex the occupied West Bank, saying that it would stop further Israeli normalisation deals with Saudi Arabia and Indonesia.

title: UK Middle East minister appears to accept 'risk of genocide' in Gaza
summary:
UK Middle East minister appears to accept 'risk of genocide' in Gaza

Britain's Middle East minister has apparently accepted that there is a "risk" of genocide in Gaza, but has been accused of misleading Labour Party members over the contents of a major UN report.

On Sunday, Hamish Falconer spoke during the Labour Party's annual conference in Liverpool in favour of a motion broadly supportive of government policy on Gaza, which Labour delegates will vote on on Monday evening.

The motion, seen by Middle East Eye, notes that on 16 September, the "United Nations Independent Commission of Inquiry found a risk of genocide against Palestinians in Gaza".

In fact, the UN report went further, and concluded that Israel has committed genocide and is still committing genocide in Gaza.

Despite this inaccuracy, Falconer's support for the motion citing the UN report indicates an acceptance that Israel has committed human rights abuses in Gaza that justify the designation of "genocide".

Read more: UK Middle East minister appears to accept 'risk of genocide' in Gaza

title: Israeli attack in southern Lebanon kills one
summary:
Israeli attack in southern Lebanon kills one

An Israeli drone strike in southern  Lebanon has killed one person, the country's National News Agency is reporting.

According to the report, the attack killed the driver of an excavator in the Shamisyah area of Shomor in the Bekaa Valley.

Footage circulating on social media appeared to show emergency teams carrying the victim away on a stretcher in the attack's aftermath.

Additionally, the agency reported that two more people were wounded in a separate Israeli attack on the main road in the southern town of Aitaroun.

summary: The Shams Tabrizi mausoleum in Khoy, northwestern Iran, is a historic monument dating back to the Safavid period (1501-1736), featuring a cylindrical tower adorned with ram horns and animal skulls, reportedly added by Shah Ismail (1487-1524) to display the kingâ€™s hunting prowess.
